Nothing is said in it about the capital to be provided by each—I bought the stock with my own money, because the defendant was sole manager—I will swear that every penny piece that was put into that business was put in by me—I put in over 2,000l. in the shape of fixtures and stock—I got the money from Mr. Cunha and Mr. Hartop—I have not got the bankers' book here, but I have produced it before and can again, if you wish it—I have receipts to show that I purchased the stock of the Old Yorkshire—I have been subpoenaed here, but not to produce any books—I sent to the Ben Jonson for the wine, which I handed to the official of the Bankruptcy Court in the beginning of September, not later—I gave it up because I was told by my solicitor that according to the new Bankruptcy Act it was an undue preference to give it to one creditor—Mr. Cunha was a creditor—I never took it to the Yorkshire, I removed it direct to my establishment in Winchester Buildings—I do not owe rent there—the landlord had asked me for the rent and I had not paid it—600l. was owing to the defendant when we dissolved partnership on 8th September—I was manager to Cunha and Nephew—he has gone to Madeira because one of his partners died—they are general wine merchants—some of the stock belonged to them and some to the defendant.

Cross-examined. All the wines which I read out, the defendant gave his acceptance to Cunha and Nephew for—I was then manager—since then Mr. Cunha has gone to Madeira and I have taken the business—I pressed the defendant to pay, and when my solicitor said it was an undue preference I volunteered to give them up to the Receiver in Bankruptcy—the defendant has not paid one penny in the Yorkshire—I was not supposed to produce documents—I have got documents to prove what I say—I have seen in the Ben Jonson and the Falcon—I have heard Mr. Solomon's evidence as to the value of the stock; it is a downright false
hood.
NOT GUILTY .

468.
DANIEL CLEARY,
Stealing a watch, the goods of
William Thomas Tranter from his person.

WILLIAM THOMAS TRANTER . I live at Fownall, Hereford—on 8th March I was staying at 7, Bridgwater Square, and about 20 minutes past 11 I was in Tranter's Temperance Hotel, and went out with three or four others to look at a fire in Aldersgate Street, near the Manchester Hotel—I noticed the prisoner and two other men near me—the prisoner put his hand across his coat—not suspecting anything, I went to button up my coat and saw the prisoner's hand go directly from my pocket—I looked down and saw my chain hanging in front me; the swivel was broken and my watch gone—I have not seen my watch since—immediately I saw his hand go away I turned to the proprietor of the hotel, and Murphy, a gentleman standing near, and said (the prisoner could hear me) "I have had my pocket picked of my watch, and that man has it"—my friend said "Get a policeman"; the prisoner and the other man moved off immediately and went and spoke to a constable who was keeping the crowd off—an inspector went across the street and they were taken as they were going down Aldersgate Street together—I never had my eyes off the prisoner.

Cross-examined by the Prisoner. I was standing between the hotel and the Metropolitan Station in the middle of the road, there was no one between us within a distance of 20 feet—I never had my eyes off you from the time I lost my watch till the time you were taken—the other prisoner was discharged—the detective told me he knew you were an old hand.

ERNEST KIDNER . (City Policeman 163). About half-past 11 on the evening of 8th March I was on duty at a fire in Aldersgate Street—my attention was called by the prosecutor to the prisoner and another man named Bryan, saying "I will give them in custody for stealing my watch"—" I and policeman 191 took them into custody—Bryan said he had never seen the prosecutor before—when taken to the station Bryan said he did not know Cleary, he had never seen him before—he was dis
charged at the police-court, no evidence being offered against him—when I took the prisoner he said "I know nothing about it; I have never seen the prosecutor before"—nothing was found on him.

p.hi: The prisoner in his defence argued that it was impossible that he could have got rid of the watch.

div1.p: GUILTY .

He then
PLEADED GUILTY to a conviction of felony in April, 1884, in the name of George Pritchard, at this Court.—
Twelve Months' Hard Labour.

469.
JOHN GIBBS and
ALFRED HUMPHREYS,
Robbery with violence on
Thomas Chaffers, and stealing a watch and chain his property.
THOMAS CHAFFERS . I live at 77, Ernest Street, Mile End, and am an insurance agent—I have served 30 years in the Army—on 7th February, between seven and eight, I was in the Whitechapel Road, and

about East Mount Street, opposite the Hospital Tavern, five men set about me; one of them came to my front—Humphreys put his hand under my overcoat and tried to get my gold albert and watch, at the same time I received a blow at the back of my head from Gibbs, who knocked me at the same time on my left leg and threw me forward violently on the ground—I got up and attempted to go after Humphreys—they had all gone away, but Humphreys, who had stolen my watch, had not got so far away as the others—before I had got two yards I was tripped up by Gibbs and thrown violently to the ground again; I tried my best to go after them and sang out "Stop thief" and "Police," but found they had got too far from me; I went to the station and gave the description of these two men and also of the property I had lost—I have never seen my watch and chain since, they were worth £7 10s.—I saw the prisoners eight or ten days afterwards and identified them from twelve others at the police-court—I have not the slightest hesitation—this happened in the wide open Whitechapel Road; I should think there were twelve lights outside the Hospital Tavern, within four yards of this—it was as light as day and I saw the prisoners distinctly—there were five men altogether, three had gone on and Gibbs and Humphreys were behind—I have no doubt about them—I was laid up for a week and have still a bandage on.
Cross-examined by Gibbs. I reported at the police-station within twenty minutes after it happened—I did not come to identify you with another prosecutor nor with a detective.
Re-examined. The detective did not give me the slightest hint as to which one to pick out.

PAYNE (Detective Officer). On 10th March I went with another con
stable to a beer-shop in King Edward Street, Mile End, and in the tap-room saw Gibbs and Humphreys—I told Gibbs I should take him for committing several larcenies from the person on different dates; he said "All right"—on the way to the station he said "You will get it up for me"—at the station he was placed with ten or twelve others and identified at once by Chaffers; when charged he said nothing—I found on him 13s. in silver and some coppers, a chain, a key and a knife.

Cross-examined by Gibbs. The conversation was just outside the public-house—I did not take you before because I had no idea before that you were the man who was doing these larcenies; it was from information I had afterwards, and I took you the night after I got it—I have not stopped you in my life except when I have taken you into custody—I got a description of you from the information—you were not put under the standard.
Re-examined. I had not seen Gibbs from nine to twelve months, I should think, before I took him.

ALFRED GOULD (Detective H). I went with Payne to this beerhouse in King Edward Street—I saw Humphreys there, and directed an officer to take him—he was told in my presence that if identified he would be charged with being concerned with others in committing various larcenies from the person—he said, "All right, I will go"—at the station he was placed with about ten others, and was immediately identified by the prosecutor—he made no reply when charged—I gave the prosecutor no description and no hint as to the men.
Cross-examined by Humphreys. I did not say when Gibbs was taken, "We must have another one"—I directed them to take you.

p.hi: Gibbs stated in his defence that he was a ticket-of-leave man, and that the detective had an animosity against him. Humphreys asserted hit innocence, and said that the man who did it was described as a dark man, and that he was not dark.

div1.p: GUILTY .

GIBBS then PLEADED GUILTY.** to a conviction of felony in December, 1879. There were two other indictments fir similar offences against Gibbs.—
Seven Years' Penal Servitude.

HUMPHREYS*†—
Eighteen Months' Hard Labour.

470.
JOHN THOMAS LOCKHART (20)
, Forging an autherity for the payment of money, with intent to defraud.

GARDNER FRENCH . I live at 32, Catherine Street, Canning Town—I am a crane driver—I have been working for Messrs. Cory and Sons—on 6th March they owed me 1l. 1s. for my week's wages—Mr. Keeble is their cashier, whose duty it is to pay my wages—I owe the prisoner 15s.—this document is signed in my name; it is not my signature; I did not authorize anybody to write it. (Read: "Mr. Keeble,—Please to give bearer my money; you will oblige me.—G. FRENCH.") On 6th March, when I went to ask for my wages, in consequence of what I heard I went to look after the prisoner with a police-constable—I found him at his lodgings; I showed him the document; I said, "Have you sent for my money?"—he said "Yes"—I received the document from Messrs. Cory in pieces—I gave the prisoner in custody.
Cross-examined by the Prisoner. I did not owe you 22s. 6d., only 15s.—the money was lent.

JAMES ALLEN KEEBLE . I live at Banner House, Upton Manor—I am cashier to Messrs. Cory and Sons—French is in Messrs. Cory's employ—on 6th March he was entitled to 1l. 1s. in wages—the document produced was brought to me by a little boy—on the faith of it I handed the boy 1l. 1s., believing it to be genuine and signed by French.

GEORGE OFFORD (Policeman). On 6th March I went with French to the prisoner's house—I saw French show the prisoner this document—the prisoner said, "I admit writing the note because you owed me money and would not pay me, and I thought that was the best way to get it"—then I took him in custody.
The Prisoner's Statement before the Magistrate." I do not wish to say anything, only he owed me money, and that was the only way to get it; I had been out of work so long."
NOT GUILTY .

471.
HENRY McMAHON (19)
, Burglary in the dwelling-house of
Henry Schlosser and stealing 9 oz. of tobacco and 5s.
GEORGE THREADGOLD . I am a carpenter, of 22, High Street, Stratford—about 12.45 on 21st March I was outside the Serpent beerhouse with

Mrs. Schlosser's eldest daughter—I noticed a bright light in the bar; I saw the prisoner and another man in the bar; the other man had the till in his hand—the daughter screamed out, "Oh, my mother is being robbed"—they made off through the kitchen and back door—I followed them; I got the key of the front door; I entered the house—I saw the two men getting over the wall; I followed them into the timber yard, there I lost sight of them—I went to the house to see what was lost—I found this hat; it fits the prisoner.

Cross-examined by the Prisoner. I gave information to the police as soon as they came up, about ten minutes to one—I watched you about three minutes, so that we should be able to take you—I gave descrip
tions of you and the other man.

GEORGE SMITH . I live at 26, Maryland Street, Stratford—I am employed by the Great Eastern Bail way Company—about 12.45 on 21st March I went into the Serpent beer-house—I saw the prisoner making his escape over the wall—I followed him with Threadgold, and was with Threadgold when the hat was found.

HANNAH SCHLOSSER . I am the wife of Henry Schlosser, the proprietor of the Serpent beer-house, 33, High Street, Deptford—on 21st March I closed the premises about 11 o'clock—every door and window was fastened properly—by the back door there is a window which cannot be opened—after the burglary I found one window opened—the bolts of the door were pushed back—the bolts can be reached from the window by a stick—a broomstick was found near the window—I missed 5s. in coppers, and about 18 or 20 half ounces of tobacco—it was all safe before I left the house—we were going back there to sleep.

THOMAS GAMES (Policeman K 372). Between 2 and 3 p.m. on 21st March, in consequence of what I was told I went to Meeson's Wharf, High Street, Stratford—I saw the prisoner; I told him I should take him into custody for breaking into Mr. Schlosser's beer-house about a quarter to 12—he said "What, me? I was in bed at a quarter to 12 at night"—I took him to the police station—I searched him—I found 11d. on him in bronze—he was wearing a hat, the same make as this one produced.

THOMAS WELLS TAYLOR . I keep the Bow Chambers lodging-house at Bow—the prisoner lodges there—he came in on Sunday morning, 21st March, about 1.40—I was visiting my dormitory to see who was in and who was out—I met the prisoner entering the hall, he bid me "Good night" and went to bed.
The Prisoner's Defence. I was wearing the same hat on the wharf when they took me—it is all false—I was not near the premises.

GUILTY*—Recommended to mercy on the ground that he had been led astray by the other parties .
Judgment respited.

He
PLEADED GUILTY. to a conviction of felony at West Ham, in August, 1883.—

472.
WILLIAM MEPHAM (33)
, Unlawfully and maliciously wound
ing
Margaret Webb. Second Count, assaulting her.

MARGARET WEBB . I am a widow, of 2, Saw Mill Terrace, Car Lane, Canning Town—on 20th March, about 5 p.m., I was in the Trossachs public-house, Barking, with the prisoner's wife—the prisoner came in—a gentleman asked me to drink—I did not speak to the prisoner—the

prisoner said "You b—w—, I'll treat you to a glass of poison"—I said "I was not speaking to you"—his wife was speaking to another man—I laughed at the prisoner—he said "For two pins I would hit you" and he hit me in the face, and knocked the glass I was drinking out of from my hand—he hit me twice in the house—the door was open and I went outside—the prisoner came to me again and said" I do not mind doing a nine-foot drop for you"—I picked up a stone and threw it at him, and he hit me again, and whatever he had in his hand cut mine in two places—his wife came and pulled him away—I wrapped my hand up in my dress and ran indoors—about 9.30 I went to the Boiler Makers Arms for beer—the prisoner was there—his wife was with me—she said "Come and see what you have, done to Mrs. Webb"—the prisoner would not come out—his wife fetched a constable—the prisoner was given into custody—the prisoner only one night about 11 said he objected to his wife keeping company with me.
Cross-examined by the prisoner. I saw no knife—the glass broke in the scuffle—your wife told me to go away about five o'clock.
NOT GUILTY .

473.
THOMAS STEPHEN BYRNE (22) and
ELIZA BYRNE (21)
were charged on the Coroner's Inquisition with feloniously killing and slaying
Peter Joseph Byrne.

p.hi: The Grand Jury having ignored the bill, MR. GEOGHEGAN for the prosecution offered no evidence.

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

474.
DAVID HARRIS (18)
, For an unnatural offence.

475.
ALFRED KENNEDY
PLEADED GUILTY . to unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.—
Twenty Months' Hard Labour.

476.
THOMAS CANTLIN (21) and
GEORGE TULLETT (26)
, Stealing a ton and a quarter of lead, the goods of
David Sheehan.
MESSRS. MONTAGU WILLIAMS and GOODRICH Prosecuted; MESSRS. GRAIN

DAVID SHEEHAN . I am a master lighterman, living at 685, Commercial Road East—I am in the employ of Messrs. Andover and Sons, of Upper Ordnance Wharf—on Monday, 8th March, I was employed to remove 835 pigs, or about 50 tons, of lead from a steamer lying at Nicholson's Wharf, near London Bridge, to the Ordnance Wharf at Rotherhithe—for the purpose I hired a barge named Edmund—when the barge arrived I counted the lead—that was about 3 p.m. on the 8th—on the 9th Marth, between 8 and 9 a.m. I saw the barge at Ordnance Wharf—I only found 810 pigs of toad in the barge—25 were gone—the value of the lost was about 35l.
Cross-examined by MR. RAVEN. I do not know Fitzgerald's Wharf.

WILLIAM HENRY MORETON . I am employed by Messrs. Andover and Sons—it was my duty to receive the lead at the warehouse—I did so on 9th March, about 9.30—I counted and found 810 pigs of lead—I have since seen the 25 pigs of lead which were found by the police—they have the same mark as these found in the warehouse.

Cross-examined by MR. RAVEN. This is what is called a pig of lead (produced)—it weighs about 1 1/4 cwt.—the mark on it is "E" over the word "Cartagenera"—that means the manufacturer in Spain—anybody could buy the lead—I have only sworn that ours bean a similar mark.
Re-examined. Twenty-five pigs of lead were lost and twenty-five were found.

FREDRICK LONDON (Thames Police Inspector). In consequence of robberies at Ordnance Wharf I received orders to watch—on Tuesday, 9th March, at 2.40 a.m. I was rowing by Ordnance Wharf—I saw a strange boat lying at Pagent's Stairs, Rotherhithe—I got into the boat with a lamp—on the sculls I found branded the words "W. Burbury"—the Edmund was lying about 30 yards off—I looked into the Edmund—the cargo appeared undisturbed.

Cross-examined by MR. RAVEN. Each of the stacks of lead had been marked on the top with a whitewashed broad streak each way, and I saw that streak about 3 o'clock, that was after I had been in the boat—I left the boat and the sculls precisely as I saw them—I saw no one about—I do not know Fitzgerald's Wharf—I was examined at the police-court—I heard Fitzgerald's Yard mentioned, but I do not know where it is—Deptford Cattle Market is about a mile and a half from Ordnance Wharf.

JOHN BURBURY . My father's name is William—I have seen the boat and the sculls with "W. Burbury" upon them at Wapping Station—my father sold that boat to Cantlin—I was present when he paid the deposit, and I made out the receipt—on 9th March I saw Cantlin about 7.15 by Huntley's Wharf, near Billingsgate Dock, Greenwich, about a quarter or half a mile from Anchor Wharf, where the pigs of lead were found—I met Cantlin the same evening, and made a communication to him.

Cross-examined by MR. RAVEN. I said "Good morning" to Cantlin—I was called before the Magistrate at Greenwich, but did not give evidence—the solicitor said I was not required—my name was not called out when the others were—I was sworn because I kissed the book, and I answered what they asked me, but they said I was no good—I do not know what I have come here for.

GEORGE DIETT . I am 16 years old—I live at 26, Conley Street, Greenwich, and am a bargebuilder's assistant—I know the prisoners—on Tuesday, 9th March, I saw them about 5.50 a.m. in their boat, which was made fast to the Granalithic stern rope, which was lying off Parish Wharf—they walked ashore after they had made the boat fast, and came back about 6.10—they took one scull and felt about where the lead was lying under the water; the tide was not far enough down for them to get at it—when the tide went down I saw the lead on the shore—they fished it up and put it into the boat, and went away with two lots—I saw them at first for about five minutes, and then I had to get on with my work—I was washing the shore—the second time I saw them about ten minutes—that morning was the first time I had seen them—I was taken to the
police-station by Sergeants Wright and Howard—I picked Cantlin out of others, and on another occasion picked out Tullett—I am positive the prisoners are the men I saw.

Cross-examined by MR. RAVEN. I said at the police-court "If I have made a mistake in one I should not make a mistake in both"—I do not know Fitzgerald's Yard—Cantlin had a moleskin guernsey and a white neck handkerchief; I think Tullett had cloth trousers and a guernsey on—I am sure both had white chokers and one a guernsey—I think Cantlin had a waistcoat over his guernsey—I have talked about what I saw—it was not light on the 9th, and it was not dark; it was middle—I have to turn out at 5 to wash the shore to catch the tide; there is mud on the shore, and I have to scrape it away from where we have to work—the prisoners were 400 or 500 yards from me, they saw me and looked at me, but they did not say a word—I did not say anything to them—when they looked at me they were on a barge called the Sam—they got out of the boat, crossed the barge, and waited ashore—I saw no other men except Taylor, the mate of the Granalithic; he is here—I saw the prisoners feeling in the water as if for lead.

HENRY STONEHAM . I live at 32, Chester Street, East Greenwich—I am a lighterman, and foreman to a barge builder, Mr. F. A. Hughes—on 9th March I saw the prisoners, about 6 a.m., on Parish Wharf, belonging to the London and Tilbury lighters Company—about 6.15 I went on the shore and unlocked the premises where I am foreman—I saw Cantlin in a boat, and Tullett on shore pitching lead into the water off the shore, about 80 feet from me—I gave information to the police.

Cross-examined by MR. RAVEN. I know the exact time when I saw them—there is a clock at Mowlem's stone wharf—the second time was from 6.15 to 6.30—"About 6.30 or 7 I came on shore and saw top on the shore the prisoner Tullett," is false—that was after the information was given; it was before the half-hour when I saw them—Cantlin was in the boat alongside the Granalithic.

WILLIAM TAYLOR . On-9th March I was living on board the barge Granalithic—I saw two men on a barge outside Parish Wharf; Cantlin was one, he asked me to give them a step into the boat, which was made fast to my barge's stern—I saw two or three pigs of lead in the boat's bottom.

Cross-examined by MR. RATON. It was on a Tuesday; I know that, because I looked in the almanack to put the cargoes down in the cargo-book—we enter it every time a freight is finished, sometimes once a week sometimes once a fortnight, not oftener than twice a week—it was a cargo of coals to London in Mr. West's barge—it was about 10 a.m. when I put them down—the men were strangers to me; I think they had Guernsey's on—I saw Diett on the shore, I was not helping him, but I was washing the shore for another purpose—I saw the men first for about ten minutes, and the second time for about five minutes.

JAMES HAYES (Thames Police Inspector). I received information from Stoneham about 6.30 on 9th March, in consequence of which I went with Giles, another constable—I landed him at Union Wharf, and he ran down the bank of the river—I sent in a boat to Parish Wharf—I found buried in the mud seven pigs of lead—I walked along the shore, and searched several places—under Anchor Wharf I found 18 pigs more close to the shore—I took them to the Wapping Police-station—at Parish
Wharf, where the seven pigs were, I found Cantlin's boat, with "Burbury," on the sculls.
Cross-examined by MR. RAVEN. Fitzgerald's Wharf is about 200 yards from the river—the Apple Water Gate would be the nearest landing to it—that is two miles off Ordnance Wharf.

RICHARD GILES (Thames Policeman). On 9th March, about 6.30, I walked down the bank of the river, in consequence of orders from my superior officer—close by Parish Wharf I saw the prisoners—I after
wards identified them.

Cross-examined by MR. RAVEN. Cantlin had an old reefing jacket—I am not certain whether he had a handkerchief—Tullett had black trousers, rather tight in the leg, a darkish-coloured overcoat, and a handkerchief round his neck—I looked at them about four minutes—they must have seen me, I was not two yards from them—I did not speak to them—I was dressed as I am now—I identified them on 17th March—I had seen Tullett on the Sunday between March 9th and 17th—I had been away part of the time—Parish and Anchor Wharves are about 350 or 400 yards apart.

GEORGE WRIGHT (Thames Police Sergeant). On Tuesday, 9th March, about 9.30 p.m., I took Cantlin into custody at The Feathers public-house, Deptford Green—I said, "I am going to take you into custody for being concerned, with another man, in stealing 25 pigs of lead this morning from the barge Edmund on a navigable river"—he said, "I do not know anything about it"—I said, "I am told you do, and that the boat belonged to you"—he said, "Yes, that is my boat, I had it stolen from me"—I said, "When?"—he said, "Last Friday"—I said, "Have you given information to the police?"—he said, "No, but I was going to Wapping Station to-night, but it is too late now"—he was taken to Deptford Road Station, where he was identified from eight or nine others by Taylor, and Diett, and Stoneham, one after the other—on 10th March, when bringing Cantlin to the police-station, he said to one of the bystanders, "Tell George to shoot the moon"—Tullett's name is George.
Cross-examined by MR. RAVEN. Cantlin was dressed when identified as he is now—I believe he had a guernsey under his waistcoat—George Tullett was taken into custody five days afterwards.

SAMUEL HOWARD (Thames Police Sergeant). On 14th March I saw Tullett at 38, Deptford Green—I said, "I want you, George"—he said, "You can't come in, my wife is in bed"—this was shortly after 9—I said, "lam coming in"—I followed him, pushed the door in, and said, "I am going to take you into custody for being concerned, with Thomas Cantlin, in stealing 35 pigs of lead from a barge lying off Ordnance Wharf, Rotherhithe, on the 9th"—he said, "The 9th! that was on Tuesday; I was dredging on the Point with my father," meaning Black wall Point—on the way to the station he said, "I suppose you have taken me as I was in trouble with him last time"—he was identified by Diett and Stoneham on 9th—I found in Cantlin's pocket a neck-handkerchief and a knife.

Cross-examined by MR. RAVEN. I did not mention about the handker
chief and knife at the police-court—Cantlin had a reefing jacket on, the same as he has now.

PATRICK FITZGERALD . I am a carman to my father—he has a wharf at Dock Street, Deptford, called Fitzgerald's Yard—I saw Cantlin the morning of the day he was locked up, about 6 o'clock, in the yard—he came for work—he had worked for us before—he had been in the yard since 4 o'clock—the morning after his mother came to me and spoke to me—then I went to the solicitor, and afterwards to the police-court.

Cross-examined. I was sleepy on the 9th—I said before the Magistrate I could not tell what the time was because I was drowsy—I had not left work till 2 a.m.—Cantlin had worked for us two years before—he was always in the yard.
Re-examined. My boy comes at 5 o'clock—he was in the yard, and the chaps—the horses are harnessed at 6—Leary was in the yard that morning—I saw him soon after 5 o'clock.

MICHAEL HOWARD . I live at 9, Barnes Alley, Deptford—I am one of Fitzgerald's carmen—on Tuesday morning I went to the yard at 5 a.m.—I cleaned the horses in the stable—I saw Cantlin at 6 o'clock or a little after, speaking to my foreman, young Fitzgerald, the last witness—I had seen him before.
Cross-examined. I said before the Magistrate I had known Cantlin for eight or nine years—he has worked for the same master as I have—he used to come every morning for a job between 5 and 6 o'clock.

JOHN LEARY . I am a carman at Fitzgerald's Yard—I was there at 5.30 on this Tuesday morning getting my horses ready—I saw Cantlin at 5.30, and again at 5.45—after 1 had put the horses in I went down to the manure factory—it is close to Deptford Creek—Cantlin rode with me as far as Noah's Ark Corner, the top of High Street, Deptford, then he said he was going to breakfast—I knew him before this—there is a clock in Fitzgerald's Yard.
Cross-examined. The clock was in the engine room—I walked round for a bit of string, and I saw through the door, which was ajar—I wanted the string to tie a pole chain—I found it on the ground.

MICHAEL HICKEY . I live at 24, Queen Street, Deptford—I am one of Fitzgerald's carmen—I was getting my horses out on this Tuesday morn
ing—I went about 5 a.m.—about half an hour after I saw Cantlin come in the yard and speak to young Fitzgerald—10 minutes afterwards the engineers' bell struck, which goes at 5.45—it rings for 10 minutes, then leaves off, and rings again at two minutes to 6—I afterwards saw Cantlin go through the yard, and with a boy, in the direction of the manure factory—I have known Cantlin some time.

Cross-examined. I have known him eight or nine years—I have worked with him—I said before the Magistrate that young Mr. Fitzgerald, my master, had sent Cantlin to the manure factory—I heard him say he might get a job if he went there.

PATRICK FITZGERALD (Re-examined). I told Cantlin I had no work, but he might get a job at the manure factory—I used to tell him where he might get jobs—I know "Joe," as we call him, of the manure factory.

PATRICK CURRAN . I live at 3, Queen's Court, Deptford—on 9th March I was standing against a public-house, when I saw Cantlin come out of the yard, 70 yards off—I asked him where he was going—he said "For
work to the manure factory"—he was in a van with Leary—that was about 6.10 a.m.—I did that day's work at Mill wall Docks.
Cross-examined. I did not say at the police-court, but I know it was the 9th.

JOSEPH WOODWARD . I am foreman at Kent's Patent Manure Wharf, Deptford—the clock is in the engine room; there is no clock in the yard—the boy Leary came in the yard by himself; Cantlin was not with him—I let Leary out; that is the boy (Leary).

Cross-examined. I was at work at six—I know it was the 9th because we bagged the stuff and sent it away that day—there was stuff bagged the next day and the day after—I had let the boy out some days before—he had come to the yard frequently—it was ten minutes to nine when I asked Leary if he was ready to go out.

GUILTY **.—Tullett then
PLEADED GUILTY to a conviction of felony in April, 1885, at the Middlesex Sessions.—
Two Years' Hard Labour each.

477.
ARTHUR JONES (25)
PLEADED GUILTY to unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.—
Eighteen Months' Hard Labour.

478.
EDGAR WILLIAM BATEMAN (29)
PLEADED GUILTY to felo
niously marrying
Emily Lilian Goodwin, his wife being alive, and to a conviction of felony at Dorchester in April, 1880.—
Four Months' Hard Labour.

479.
JOHN PENNY (18)
, Stealing a purse and 8s. 11 3/4 d., the goods and money of
Thomas Hard, from the person of
Matilda Hard.

MATILDA HARD . I am the wife of Thomas Hard, of 22, Loughborough Road, Peckham—on 12th March I was in the Deptford Broadway between 3 and 4 p.m.—a child called my attention to a man's hand in my bag—I saw the man with my purse—I called out, and he dropped the purse into my hand—I saw my bag was open—I tried to catch hold of the prisoner by his coat sleeve, and said, "You have my purse," and he dropped it into my hand as my hand was holding the handle of my bag—I next saw him at the police-station, where I recognised him from others.

Cross-examined by the Prisoner. I am sure it was you from the colour of your coat and appearance, and your eyes—you forced the purse back into my hand—though I was faint at the time I am sure it was you.

SAMUEL CARTER (Police Inspector R). I was in Deptford Broadway about 3.35 p.m.—the thoroughfare was crowded in consequence of the visit of the Princess Louise—I heard a cry of "Police"—I was outside the crowd—I looked towards the spot; I saw the prisoner running away from the crowd—I ran after the prisoner, whom I saw running; I stopped him—from what I heard I took him to the station—in answer to something that was said in the crowd on the way to the station he said, "I have not got anything," or "I have not got the purse," or something similar—I made inquiries; I met the prosecutrix coming towards the station—I placed the prisoner with eight or nine other men and the pro
secutrix immediately picked him out as the man who was there.
Cross-examined by the Prisoner. A shopkeeper pushed you into my arms; you were not running towards me.
ALICE HUBBARD . I saw the prisoner with his hand in Mrs. Hard's bag—he took something out—I knocked her arm and told her the man had taken something out of her bag.
Cross-examined by the Prisoner. The lady was in a crowd.

GUILTY **.—He then
PLEADED GUILTYict> to a conviction of felony at this Court in June, 1885, in the name of John Jones.—
Eighteen Months' Hard Labour.

480.
GEORGE TARELLI (40)
, Unlawfully obtaining from
Henry Franklin and another certain moneys with intent to defraud, and attempt
ing to obtain money with a like intent.

HENRY FRANKLIN . I am one of the firm of H. H. Franklin, printers, of 7, Pocock Street, Blackfriars Road—in July last we had a correspon
dence with the prisoner at Gateshead and ultimately appointed him our agent, and sent him this document (produced)—the terms agreed on between us were 12 1/2 per cent, commission, 2 1/2 per cent to be retained in our hands until the end of each six months—we received a letter from him asking that the 12 1/2 per cent, should be paid in full every week, and that was done—my cousin is the principal partner.

Cross-examined by the Prisoner. We did not owe you 6l. 8s. on 1st September—there was an amount of 3l. 3s. at the end of August, but we had certain amounts to your debit—we had several complaints from customers you had taken orders from, complaining they had given you orders less than you gave us, and we had to take money off them, and we said we proposed to take the balance of 3l. 8s. as your share of the amounts we had lost through you—we did not send goods above the orders you sent—producing certain amounts necessitates our sending sometimes more or less, but in no case did the excess amount to 1,000 in 10,000, but there were complaints of receiving 20,000 instead of 10,000.

HENRY FRANKLIN the elder. I am a partner in this firm—in December I received this order (produced) from the prisoner for 50,000 handbills for Jane Anne Clarke, of Newcastle—that amounted to 6l. odd—I received an order for 50,000 cards for Ryan, of Newcastle, which came to 6l. 5s.—this is the order, in the prisoner's handwriting, signed by Ryan, and this is the prisoner's receipt for 6l. 5s.—I also received an order for Jackson and Co., of Newcastle, for 100,000 handbills, amounting to 8l. 6s. 8d., and this one for Budge, of Heaton, for 50,000 cards, amounting to 6l. 5s.—this signature is supposed to be Rudge's—I sent off Mrs. Clarke's order—we do not pay the carriage, and those goods are still in the hands of the railway company—they made a claim on us for carriage, and we instructed them to destroy the goods—I sent this bill for 7l. 11s. 3d. for 55,000 to Mrs'. Clarke for them—the goods sent to Jackson and Co. are still in the railway company's hands—we are liable for the carriage—in both those cases we received no value for the goods—the railway company said they could not find Rudge, of

Heaton—this claim for 3l. 9s. 2d. for commission on account of Ryan and Bulge is in the prisoner's handwriting—we paid him 2l. on account of it and his receipt appears on the document; the real commission of what was due on those orders would be 17s.—on 30th November we received an order through the prisoner for Maltini, of Newcastle, for 50,000 handbills, value 6l. 17s. 6d., and we received this order purporting to be signed John Reed, "Please supply on usual terms, 50,000"—we also received this document, setting out Maltini 6l. 5s. and Reed 6l. 17s., and claiming commission of 1l. 13s. 6d., in the prisoner's writing—I sent him that amount and the receipt is pasted on the document—we got no money from Maltini—we found him; we evidently instructed our solicitor to sue him, but from what we heard did not go on with the action—on 17th December I received this order, marked F, for 100,000 handbills for Baldwin, of 17, New Bridge-street, Newcastle, 7l. 15s., from the prisoner—in consequence of what we heard we did not execute that order—in those cases whore we paid the prisoner the commission we did so because we believed at the time the orders were bona fide and that commission was due.

Cross-examined by the Prisoner. We did not send you £2 at the end of the year and leave a balance of £4 8s. in your favour—the whole of your claim has been settled up—each transaction has been complete in itself and the receipt at the bottom has settled each matter, you had no after claim to make at all—you never wrote to us with respect to making any claim to commission on bills sent in excess; this is the first I hear of claiming fancied commission on orders.

By the COURT. He entered our service six months prior to December—it is unreasonable to expect we can go back over the whole of the trans
actions, inasmuch as each document closes each transaction—the general counting-house business does not go through my hands, but I can speak to these.

JANE ANN CLARKE . I live at 2, Ingham Place, Newcastle—on 13th December I kept a milliner's shop at Ridley Street, and on that day the prisoner called and asked for an order for handbills, and I gave him an order for 5,000, not for 50,000—I gave him this order (produced) signed for 5,000 in pencil; that has since been transmogrified into 50,000 in ink—about a fortnight after the time at which the bills should have been delivered the prisoner called again—I told him I had not received the bills, and they would be no use to me now as I was going to leave—they had not then come—I afterwards received a notice from the Railway Company that the goods were at the station.

THOMAS JACKSON . I am a clothier, of 40, Grainger Street, Newcastle—in October last I gave the prisoner an order for 25,000 handbills, which were supplied—about December the prisoner called on me and I gave him an order for 25,000 handbills of a peculiar pattern—I received 30,000, and subsequently I received 100,000 which I had not ordered, a different lot altogether—I wrote to Messrs. Franklin that they were of no use to me and that I had never ordered them, and I refused to take them.
Cross-examined. I signed the first order—Franklin sent me 30,000 instead of 25,000—I got no proof of the bill, but 30,000 of them.
ANGELO MALTINI . I am a carver and gilder at Newcastle—the prisoner called on me a fortnight before Christmas and asked for an

order for some address cards, and I signed an order for 5,000—sub
sequently I received this card from the Railway Company claiming a sum of 10s. 4d. for the delivery of 50,000 cards—I wrote to Messrs. Franklin about it and refused to take them in.

JOHN REED . I am a boot and shoe maker, of 36, Victoria Street, near Newcastle-on-Tyne—in the first week in December the prisoner called on me to solicit an order for handbills, and I gave him an order for 25,000 at 2s. 9d. per 1,000—I signed this blank order; this is my name—I see here 50,000, I did not write that, and did not give an order for 50,000 but for 25,000—the bills were delivered to me and I declined to accept them—I wrote this 25,000 bills on the form myself and signed it—I signed two orders, because I asked him to put the terms on one paper, and then he gave me a blank order to sign—the 25,000 one he drew up in my presence and the other I signed in blank, in which he afterwards put 50,000.
Cross-examined. I received 60,000 bills, invoiced at 2s. 9d.

WALTER SAYER . I am a picture frame maker, of 17, New Bridge Street, Newcastle—I have lived there four years—no persons named Baldwin & Co. have carried on business there while I have been there—nor in that street that I am aware of—I was the only person carrying on business in December, 1885, at No. 17.

DAVID WRIGHT . I am rate collector at Bicker, near Newcastle-on-Tyne—I know the place well for nine months—there is no such place as Shields Road, Heaton—there is a Shields Road, Bicker; my office is there and I have been there nearly twelve months—there was no person of the name of Budge carrying on business in Shields Road, Bicker—Heaton and Bicker are adjacent, no person named Budge was living there.

GEORGE THOMAS MARTIN (Police Sergeant M). On Saturday, 6th March, in consequence of a telegram I received from Newcastle I went there, and on the 8th I saw the prisoner in custody at the station—I asked him if the warrant had been read to him and he understood what he was charged with—I said "The money which is referred to is on account of Baldwin and Rudge's orders"—he said "Baldwin and Rudge gave the orders as they were going to commence business, but had not settled as to what place, and wanted the orders kept over till April; I know them, but don't know their address"—before he said that I had told him that Baldwin and Budge could not be found at the address given—I said "Other orders have been increased"—he said "I have never increased one order and have about £10 due on the fund account," I understood by that commission that was left back on account of the 2 1/2 per cent—I said "Can you tell me where to see Budge or Baldwin"—he said "No"—he also said "The firm are in the habit of sending more goods than are ordered."

GUILTY .*—
Eighteen Months' Hard Labour.

481.
ALFRED BAILEY
, Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.
JOHN CURRAN GRAY . I managed the Black Bull, Old Kent Road—at 11.30 p.m. on 11th March, the prisoner came in for twopenny worth of Irish whisky, and tendered a bad shilling—I broke it in a teeter—he
said he had changed a half-sovereign in another house, and had it in change—I gave him one-half and kept this other (produced) which I gave to the constable—I believe it is the same.
Cross-examined by the Prisoner. You asked for the piece back that you might get it rectified at the place you took it at.
Re-examined. The prisoner was perfectly sober.

CUTHBERT WALTER CHAMPION . I am foreman in the employ of Henry Love and Co., 24, Guildford Street—about 11.35 p.m. on 11th March, I was in the Black Bull when the prisoner came in—I have heard the last witness give his evidence—I corroborate him—when the prisoner left the house I followed him along the Dover Road until he reached another public-house, into each bar of which he looked, but did not enter—I missed him for a moment, and later on, as I was returning to the Black Bull about a quarter of an hour after, I saw him outside the Beehive—he went in, and I followed and made a communication to the landlord.

THOMAS LONDON . I keep the Beehive, in Warner Street—shortly before 12 on the 11th March, the prisoner came in for a half-pint of six ale—I saw my sister serving him—he tendered a shilling to her; in consequence of a communication made to me by Champion, I said "Give that to me"—I looked at it and bent it in my teeth—I then showed it to the prisoner, and asked him if he knew what it was—he said "What do you mean?"—I said "I will show you what I mean, I will call a constable"—the potman fetched a constable, and I gave him in charge—the prisoner said nothing—he was sober.
Cross-examined by the Prisoner. You did not attempt to hurry away when I accused you—I put my hand over the counter and held your arm—I gave the coin to Whisker.

THOMAS WHISKER (Policeman M 370). At five to minutes 12 on 11th March I was called to the Beehive—the landlord gave the prisoner into my custody with this bad shilling and charged him—he made no reply—I searched him and found part of another shilling—next day I received from Mr. Gray part of a broken shilling, which fits into the piece I found—another bad shilling was found on him at the station—I found in good money on him one shilling, six sixpences, 2s. 4 3/4 s. in bronze, a ring and a knife, lying loose in all his pockets.

Cross-examined. You made no resistance when I came into the bar—you allowed me to search you; the landlord had you jammed against the bar—you were lodging at a common lodging-house, and were employed as a casualty hand when they could get no one else as a porter.
By the COURT. There are 100 to 115 yards between the public-houses.
EDWARD HARTLAND (Policeman M 295). I assisted in the searching the prisoner at the station, and found this shilling broken in two in the left pocket of his coat tail.
WILLIAM JOHN WEBSTER . These three shillings are all bad—twelve broken ones are from the same mould.

p.hi: The prisoner in his statement before the Magistrate and in his defence stated that he must have taken the coins in change, that he did not know they were bad, and that he was the worse for drink at the time.

div1.p:
GUILTY .—
Eight Month' Hard Labour.

482.
THOMAS JONES (56) and
JAMES EVANS (20)
, PLEADED GUILTY to burglary in the dwelling-house of
Alfred Robert Jackson, having previously been convicted of felony.—
Judgment respited. And

483.
JAMES STACEY WELLER
, to stealing, while employed in the Post-office, a packet containing a pocket-book, the property of
Her Majesty's Postmaster-General.
[Pleaded Guilty: See original trial image.] He received a good character. Recom
mended to mercy by the sender of the package.—
Twelve Months' Hard Labour.

484.
GEORGE COURTIER (71)
,
PLEADED GUILTY to stealing a hand
bag and other goods, the property of
Andrew Fraser.

485.
JOHN PARMENTER
, Unlawfully and carnally knowing
Eliza
beth Jane Burn, aged 15 years and 7 months. Second Count, attempting the same.
NOT GUILTY .

486.
JAMES BROCKWELL
, Robbery with violence on
Alfred Sullivan, and stealing 47l., the moneys of the
Richmond Gas Company.
MESSRS. KEITH FRITH and WATKIN Prosecuted; MR. HORACE AVORY Defended.

ALBERT OSWALD SULLIVAN . I am a collector of gas accounts for the Richmond Gas Company—I was collecting accounts on 22nd February at Ham—I had called at the Vicarage about 10 minutes to 5—I went towards Mr. Fields by the side of the Common—I walked across the grass that borders the road—I heard footsteps, and then a remark, "Governor, give me some money"—I replied, "I have no money to give you, my man; if I had I would do so"—I received a blow on my right cheek, and was thrown—as I fell I received a kick or hit straight in the nape of my neck—I became unconscious—when I recovered I found myself in a ditch about 3 1/2 yards off—I made the best of my way to the New Inn public-house—I missed 46l. or 47l. in gold from my right-hand trousers pocket—I kept gold in one pocket, silver in another, and coppers in another—I had a 5l. note, 5 cheques, silver and coppers, which were not taken—I found my trousers slit down and the pocket cut right out—the pocket was made of a sort of chamois leather—those are the trousers produced—I observed the man for a very short time—it was daylight—I gave a description to the police—on 6th March I was with Sergeant Bush—we went into the Crooked Billet about 2 p.m.—we played at bagatelle together—I went in the bar for drink—I saw Police-constable Fry and the prisoner—directly the prisoner saw me he walked out quickly to the back yard—I made a communication to Fry—I believe he was the man who knocked me down—the prisoner was taken into custody—I went back to the spot where the assault took place—Mr. Hill, a baker, drove me to it, and Fry walked across the Common—the man who attacked me had two or three days' growth of beard—it was a little grizzly—he was dressed as the prisoner was when arrested at the Crooked Billet—I did not notice his trowsers—I only recognised him by his face—I saw these other trousers produced at the Kingston Police-court—I could not say whether the prisoner wore them.
Cross-examined. There were large hedges on my right, and furze behind

and on the left—the prisoner changed his trousers after my seeing Him at the Crooked Billet—I was perfectly sober when I was with Bush and Fry—we went to the spot the same night—it was getting dusk—I pointed out the place where I had been robbed as near as possible—the prisoner came back into the Crooked Billet after going out at the back—he had not got outside the door before I said he was the man who knocked me down—I did not say I believed it was a man named Howell who robbed me—the chairman of the Gas Company told me, as my wife was ill, I had better have a holiday; therefore I had been suspended by the Gas Company—I do not know whether that is pending this inquiry.
Re-examined. The name of the man called Howell is Brocket—the prisoner came into the bagatelle room after I pointed him out to Fry—Bush was present.

JAMES FRY (Policeman V 302). I am stationed at West Ham—on 22nd February, about 5.30, the prosecutor made a communication to me—he was rather excited—his trousers were cut at the top—I went to the spot the prosecutor indicated, and observed the ground—he made a statement to me there—on 6th March I was drinking with the prisoner in the Crooked Billet—the prosecutor came in the bar—he asked me if I would have anything to drink—I said, "No, thank you, I have got some"—the prisoner walked past the prosecutor into the back yard, when Sullivan made a communication to me—the prisoner paid for a portion of the drink—I have known him seven years—I spoke to the prosecutor when the prisoner was gone out—I went into the room where Bush and Sullivan were—Sullivan still insisted that that was the man—the prisoner had gone out—I went to the Ham Brewery, and told the prisoner that Sullivan accused him of knocking him down and robbing him—the prisoner had changed his clothes—directly after he was accused he went home—I waited for him, and he "went to Richmond Police-station with me after he had changed his clothes—these are the trowsers he had on before he changed his clothes—he had them on at the Crooked Billet—he said his clothes were dirty, and he did not want to go to Richmond Police-station in them—the prosecutor appeared at the police-station, and formally charged the prisoner with having robbed him—the prisoner had an opportunity of reply—he did not reply—the prosecutor was sober when he made the charge.

Cross-examined. I cannot say the prosecutor's excitement was due to drink—at the Brewery the prisoner, when told he was accused of the robbery, said "Never"—after he was charged he said, "I shall be able to show I was at Claridge's on that evening"—I have known him seven years as a blacksmith; I know nothing against him—he was in his working dress at the Crooked Billet—the prosecutor gave a rather rambling description, which I could not make anything of—he said the prisoner had brown trousers; these produced are not brown—I did not see the slightest sign of a scuffle on 22nd February at the spot where the robbery is said to have occurred; it was an open space on the grass; the ground was soft, and you would expect to find marks—there is a urinal in the yard at the Crooked Billet—the prisoner was outside the first door leading to the passage when the prosecutor spoke to me about him—the prisoner could have gained the road and got away from the back yard—he came back and finished his beer on the counter.
Re-examined. The prosecutor said he had been knocked down—the
weather was not frosty; the ground was quite soft; after Sullivan had been there in a light cart you could see the wheel marks for two or three days where the cart turned.

GEORGE BUSH (Detective V). On Saturday, 6th March, I was at the Crooked Billet about 2 p.m. with the prosecutor—the prisoner came into the parlour after a conversation had passed between myself and the prosecutor—the prisoner said, "Good afternoon, Mr. Bush"—he went out, then the prosecutor spoke to me—I went outside and saw the prisoner with Fry—I said to the prisoner, "Fry has told you what Sullivan said?"—the prisoner said, "Yes, we shall be able to clear that up, Mr. Bush"—I said, "The best thing is to go with us to Richmond Police-station, and perhaps the matter can be cleared up there"—he said, "I should like to have a wash before going up, I do not know what people will think"—I said "Very good," and he went and washed, and walked with us to Richmond Police-station—he was there charged by Sullivan—when the prosecutor complained of being robbed he gave me a description of the man who robbed him; I took it down in writing.

Cross-examined. The description was, "A man, age about 26, height 5 feet 3 or 4 inches, beard and whiskers sandy, of recent growth, dirty face, dressed in dark brown trousers, black morning coat, hard felt hat, blocked; can be identified"—when he gave me that description he was a little confused—this was about 6.30, the evening of the occurrence—at Richmond Police-station he seemed very much upset—I did not go to the spot that night; it was three and a half miles off, and it was dark when I saw him at the station—on the morning we went to Ham the prosecutor said he had an idea it was a man named Holmes—the prisoner is some-what of the description given—it did not occur to me to apply to him till the prosecutor spoke to me about it.

p.hi: stated that there might be some mistake, and at the suggestion of the Court offered no further evidence.

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

487.
WILLIAM LAWRENCE (32)
, Burglary in the dwelling-house of
Thomas Howell, and stealing therein a hat, an umbrella, and a knife, his goods.

THOMAS HOWELL . I am a blacksmith—about 9 p.m. on 22nd March I was in the Crown public-house with my wife, when a neighbour's child said something, in consequence of which I rushed over to the house—I found three men there; the prisoner is one—I said, "What are you doing here?"—they said, "Oh, we are mistaken, we want to go upstairs; it is not here, it is upstairs"—I said, "You won't go upstairs—they got out of the house, and I gave chase—I saw my wife's hat and umbrella in the prisoner's hand; he threw them down—I missed my wife's hat and a knife—within 10 yards I called a constable over, and told him the prisoner had broken into my house, and gave him in charge—these are the goods I missed—I used this knife as a screwdriver about a fortnight before this occurred.
Cross-examined by the Prisoner. I saw no females near the doorway.
CLARA MCGRADY . I live next door to Howell—on 22nd March I heard the breaking open of the door of Howell's house—I looked out; I saw three men round the corner, the prisoner was one—when Howell came
I saw them in the house—the prisoner said he wanted to go upstairs—Howell said, "You are not going up there," and they ran off.
ARTHUR SAPSFORD (Policeman M 99). The prisoner was given into my custody—I examined the premises—the door had been burst open, the catch had given way.
The prisoner in his defence stated he went to get 1l. 17s. from a female, and the other men tried to "shove" him out. A female said she would give him a knife if he did not go.
THOMAS HOWELL (re-examined). There are two rooms above mine, occupied by women—I do not know their names—their husbands are working men.
NOT GUILTY .

488.
JACOB MULLER (46)
, Unlawfully obtaining by false pretences pretences from
Clarence Klaus 3l. 12s. 2d., with intent to defraud. Second Count, obtaining from
Moss Wolfe a coat, a pair of trousers, and 3l. 4s. 6d., with a like intent. Another Count, conspiring with one Louis Myers and others by false pretences to cheat and defraud
Moss Wolfe.

p.hi: Prosecuted. The evidence was interpreted to the prisoner.

div1.p: LOUIS COLLINS (Detective Officer). I arrested the prisoner on 19th February—after I read the warrant to him he said, "I know nothing about the first, but in the other case of Mr. Klaus I received the cheque of a man named Drum, who lives at Islington. We went to a public-house near Mr. Liddicott's, where I filled it in. I know the man by sight, I do not know his name"—he said he met Drum in High Street, Peckham.

p.hi: Clemence Klaus being called, did not appear; he was stated to have left the country.

div1.p: MOSS WOLFE . I am a tailor, of 82, Borough High Street—on 6th February a man named Louis Myers called at my shop with a man named Muller—Muller was the name on the cheque—he was about the same height and complexion as the prisoner, but I cannot swear to him—I cannot identify tine prisoner.
NOT GUILTY .

489.
SAMUEL LOTT,
Feloniously assaulting
Diana Farrell, with intent, &c.

MR. DE MICHELE
Prosecuted; MR. H. AVORY Defended.
NOT GUILTY .

490.
CONSTANCE ELIZA MARTIN (29)
, For the wilful murder of her female child.
MR. H. AVORY Prosecuted; MR. WARBURTON Defended.

ELIZA BIRKIN . I am a widow—I lived at Claremont Villa, Woodlands Road, Redhill, in January last—the prisoner came into my service as a domestic servant on 12th January this year—I had previously seen her at Penshurst, in Kent, and had seen her aunt, Mrs. Wheatley, there—before I engaged the prisoner I noticed that she was a peculiar figure—I did not speak to her about it, but I spoke to her aunt after she had been in my service a few days—after the 12th January I found that she did not suit me, and I gave her notice on the 18th, and said that I would

try and get her another situation—I did not tell her on what day she was to go, till Friday the 22nd, and on that day, about 10 o'clock in the morning, I told her she must leave that day—I had passed her bed-room and noticed marks of blood on the floor—I spoke to her about it, and asked her if it was usual with her—she said, "Yes, once a fortnight"—it was after that that I told her that she must leave that day—later in the day my dog ran down the garden, and came back again—there is a rubbish-heap at the bottom of the garden, and when the dog came back his face was all over blood—when the prisoner saw the condition of the dog I told her to wash him—she said "He has been down to the rubbish-heap, where I went this morning"—about half-past two o'clock I sent for a cab for her to go away, and she went in the cab to the station—I saw her when she left, and saw what luggage she took with her—she had a box and three parcels wrapped up in paper—I cannot say what kind—I cannot give you any idea whether any of them was of any sue—after she had gone I went down to the garden to the rubbish-heap, and saw some
thing there—I did not think it was anything at that time, but I went again next morning, and I thought it was a miscarriage—after she went that day I went into her bed-room, but I saw no more than I saw early in the morning—I looked at the bed; it was not marked much, but it was marked with blood—when I say the same day, I mean the day that she left.

JOHN WHEATLEY . I live at Park Farm, Leigh, Kent, that is near Tunbridge—the prisoner is my niece; her father is dead and her mother is out in service—she came to stay at my house two days before Christmas, and left to go to Mrs. Birkin's situation—I noticed nothing particular about her figure then, she was always a peculiar shape—on Friday evening, 22nd Januarys I was going along the main road from Penshurst to Leigh, and about 20 minutes to 8 I passed a female in the road at Tabby's Corner, that is near some cottages called the Compasses, and about half a mile from my house—I did not know her when I passed her, she was stooping by the side of the road, and a parcel was lying in the road, at the side of the road—I passed on to my home, and about 10 minutes to 8 the prisoner arrived there—I did not know she was coming—she brought with her two small parcels—when she came she told me where she bad come from; she said she had left Mrs. Birkin's service and had been to Tunbridge and got another situation—I asked her if I had passed her in the road, and she said "Yes"—she stayed at my house until the Sunday morning and then left, saying she was going to a friend at Tunbridge and then to her aunt at Edenbridge.

CHARLES GILLETT . I live at a place called the Compasses, at Lee—on Friday evening, the 22nd of January, I was going from Leigh village to the Compasses—I did not meet Mr. Wheatley at Tilley's Corner, but just after I had passed Tabby's Corner I saw a woman in the road standing still; she was on the left-hand side of the road, going towards Leiglh—a parcel was by her side in the road: she was not doing anything with it—I looked round after I had gone by, and she was still in the same position—on the following morning I went with Police-constable Taylor and pointed out the spot to him where I had seen the woman.

JOHN WELFARE . I live near Leigh, in Kent—on Friday evening, the 22nd of January, I was going home towards Leigh, and about a quarter of a mile before I got to Tabby's Comer I saw a woman in the road; she

was carrying a parcel in front of her; as far as I could see it was a brown-paper parcel—she was going towards Leigh at the time I passed her—on the following morning (Saturday), about a quarter to eleven o'clock, I was passing Tabby's Corner on my way to work and some boys called my attention to something at the side of the road—it was a dead child—it was at the left-hand side of the road, going towards Penshurst Station—it was just over the hedge, on the field side of the hedge—it was partly wrapped in rather light-coloured paper—I have not seen the paper since—it was about a quarter of a mile from the place where I had seen the woman the night before, nearer to Leigh—I then got the station-master to telegraph to Superintendent Barnes.

ALBERT TAYLOR . I am Instructing Constable of the Kent Consta
bulary, stationed at Tunbridge—about two o'clock on Saturday, the 23rd January, in consequence of information, I went to Leigh, to a place called the Compasses, and about 70 yards from the Compasses, going from Penshurst towards Leigh village, I found first of all a sheet of brown paper with the name of Mrs. Wheatley written in black-lead pencil on it—the paper was stained with blood and matter—close to the paper was a piece of string—there was snow in the road at the time and I saw marks of blood at that spot—a few yards further down the road on the field side of the hedge I found the body of a child—the head was partly covered with snow and the legs were slightly inclined upwards—it was lying on its back, and was partly covered with lightish coloured paper and the body was covered with blood and matter—I noticed a wound under the left ear—I put the body into a basket and took it first of all to the Railway Hotel at Penshurst—on the next day I delivered it to Dr. Fraser, of Leigh—the witness Gill pointed out a spot to me in the road; that was where I found the sheet of paper.

JOHN WHEATLEY (Cross-examined by Mr. WARBURTON). I am the uncle of this girl—I have noticed her conduct to be very strange—she was always very peculiar in her habits and in her ways too—she had no delusions, but she had a very strange way, eccentric—she was what you would call weak-minded.
By MR. AVORY. She was always very peculiar in her mind, and she had a curious way of speaking—I should call her half-witted—she had been in two other situations before this.

FRANK FRAZER . I am a Doctor of Medicine, and practise at Lee, in Kent—I saw the body of a female child on Sunday, 24th January, at the Railway Hotel at Penshurst, and found that it was a fully-developed child and well nourished—externally it was very dirty, it had not been attended to since its birth—the umbilical cord had been severed about an inch and a half from the child by a clean cut—I also observed externally, about an inch above the right eyebrow, a slight bruise, which was filled with a clot, and the rim of the right ear was lacerated, but very slightly—beneath the left ear there were, two parallel wounds, the upper one an inch and a quarter beneath the ear, and one inch from it; that was superficial, simply cutting through the skin, it was a cut—the wound beneath that was of a severe nature, one inch and a quarter in length, and forked in appearance; it branched, and the fork looked outwards, away from the chin—that wound cut through the skin and muscles and chief blood-vessels, down to the bone, it divided the carotid artery, and caused the child's death—in my opinion that was the cause of death—

there was evidence of it having bled considerably, the wound itself was full of blood, and there was blood outside the wound, which was slightly gaping—on examination internally I found that the lungs had been breathed through—the rest of the organs were healthy as far as I could see—I cannot say from looking at the blood that I found in the wound and outside, whether the-wound had been inflicted after the child had breathed or before, probably after—looking at the condition of the lungs I can only say that the child had breathed.

By the COURT. The child would begin to breathe as soon as the head appeared—I do not think the wound could have been inflicted before, but the child may not have breathed for a minute after it was born—I cannot say when the child commenced to breathe.

By MR. AVORY. The lungs were fully inflated—I think the wound must have been inflicted with a sharp-cutting instrument, a table knife would do it—some degree of violence would be necessary to inflict it—as to the power required, an effort of 12 would be necessary, I think, and the point of the knife would have to be sharp.
By the COURT. The child might live half a minute after the wound in the neck, which severed the carotid, not more.

Cross-examined. In my experience there are often cases of violence being inflicted on a child before it is fully born, and therefore it comes into the world dead; it may be born dead from violence, accidental or in
tentional—the lungs being what is called crepitant simply shows that the child has breathed, but not that it has had an independent circulation—I put the lungs in water—I admit that that is no certain sign of itself—I know no cause but disease for the lungs of children who have not breathed floating on water; I mean what is called putrefaction—the fact of the child having the power of breathing before it is entirely born does not render these tests certain—I believe it is not very common for a child to breathe and yet never to live in the sense of that term—it does happen that a child breathes and yet does not get an independent circulation—the mere act of gasping in the act of being born would help to inflate the lungs—there was blood in the conium and the venix casieva; that does not necessarily prove that the child was born alive—I do not know that in cases where a woman delivers herself, the chances of a child coming into the world alive are not so great as when a medical man attends her; the operation is nature's own effort, but there might be a slight difference in cutting the umbilical cord, which in this instance was severed an inch and a half from the child; that would be the place where a medical man would sever it—it was not tied at all, and death might possibly have been caused by bleeding from it—I considered the severance properly near to the abdomen—by what is known as an independent circulation I wish the Jury to understand that that means when no blood is flowing from the mother to the child—I cannot positively state, as a medical man, that this child ever had a separate existence.

Re-examined. here was no evidence, on my examination of the child, of its having bled to death from the umbilical cord—there was no disease or putrefaction of the lungs to account for crepitation; there was nothing but the child having breathed to account for it—the child contained very little blood, but I never saw what quantity of blood came from it—of course I cannot say where the blood which was upon the body came from,

but I can say that a large quantity of blood had flowed from the wound—I am not enabled to form an opinion that because a large quantity of blood had flowed from the wound, the child had had an independent cir
culation.

By the COURT. The independent circulation begins directly the cord is tied, when the blood does not flow from the mother to the child—if the child's throat was cut before the cord was tied the mother might bleed to death as well as the child, that is to say if the connection remained.
By MR. AVORY. An independent circulation is generally set up in the child in consequence of its breathing, before it is severed from the mother.

By the COURT. When the cord is tied it sets up the action of making the child breathe; it breathes of itself, but it does not necessarily follow that the child has breathed of itself when the cord is tied, it may never breathe at all—the independent circulation becomes established at the birth—the fact of breathing generally speaking, establishes the circula
tion—supposing a wound to be inflicted on a child in the act of being born, I should expect about the same flow of blood from the wound as if it had been done after it had breathed.

By MR. WARBURTON. With regard to the question of independent circulation, the blood would cease to flow either from the tying of the cord or from its being cut; there could be no independent, circulation till one of those things was done; the cord might not be cut for two or three hours—the breathing and the independent circulation generally act together—it is almost impossible to define when the breathing would commence.
By the COURT. I think there is a very strong probability that the child was fully born.

WILLIAM ARTHUR FORD . I am one of the Kent constabulary stationed at Penshurst—on 25th January I went to Edenbridge, and saw the prisoner there at her aunt's house, and said to her "Were you at Penshurst and Leigh on Friday evening?" she said "Yes"—I then told her that I should have to charge her with the murder of her child, and cautioned her in the usual way; I said "Whatever you say will be given in evidence against you"—she said "If I speak the truth shall I get off?" I said "I don't know"—she then said "I put the child where it was found; I done it myself; I had it in my bedroom at Mrs. Birkin's, at Redhill, and I stuck it, with a table-knife; it lived about 10 minutes"—I had seen her about a fortnight before, at Christmas time, when she was at Leigh, and she looked then as if she was in the family way.
Cross-examined. There was a little conversation about family matters, I being her cousin.

EDWARD ALFRED BARNES . I am Superintendent of the Kent Constabu
lary at Tunbridge—I was at Penshurst Station when the prisoner was brought there by the last witness—I told her the inquest was being held at the public-house on the body of the child, and asked her to go into Court—she said she did not want to go, and would rather not; she said "I told Mr. Ford the truth, I don't want to say anything more"—that same evening she was taken from Penshurst to Tunbridge—I wrote the charge down on a slate and read it over to her—the charge was that of mur
dering her child in the parish of Leigh, in Kent—she said "No, it was not

was not at Leigh, it was at Redhill; I think it lived about ten minutes"—on the following morning, Tuesday, the 26th, just before the Magis
trates met, she sent for me, and said she hoped she would not have to say much when she rot into Court—later in the day she said "The young man who is the father of the child promised to marry me after hop
picking, he then threw me up; my father is dead, my mother is in service, I had nowhere to go, and did not know what to do; I am very sorry if I have done anything very wrong."

GEORGE ROGERS . I am Superintendent of the Reigate Borough Police—I fetched the prisoner from Tunbridge to Reigate on Saturday, 80th January—I told her who I was, and that I should take her back to Reigate or Redhill to be charged with the murder of her child; I had cautioned her previously—she said nothing then, but on the road from Tunbridge to Redhill she said she was very sorry, she did not know how she came to do it—I think she said the child had been born about 2 or 8 o'clock in the morning.

hi.rs: GUILTY of endeavouring to conceal the birth.—

div1.p:
491.
JOHN MOY (40)
, Burglary in the dwelling-house of
William Glover, with intent to steal.

CHARLES ROCK . (Policeman N 311). On 27th February I was on duty near Queen's Boad, Clapham Park—about 1 a.m. I heard glass breaking, and saw the prisoner and another man run away from a house and across the lawn—I chased them across some meadows—the prisoner got over a fence and tried to conceal himself under a hedge—I asked him his busi
ness there; he made no answer—I took him to the station and found a clasp knife and a box of matches on him—he was charged with breaking into The Firs; he made no answer.

MATILDA CROFT . I am cook to Mr. William Glover, of the Firs, Clapham Common—on 26th February I saw the house fastened up securely, next morning I found a piece cut out of a pane of glass, and the panel of the inside shutter forced out.

ALFRED EASTON (Police Inspector). On 27th February I went to The Firs, and found two bars of the kitchen window bent, the window broken, the catch broken, and the window open; considerable force had been used.

p.hi: The prisoner produced a written defence, stating that he had been lyiny under a hedge three hours, and knew nothing of the house being broken into.

div1.p:
GUILTY .—
Six Months' Hard Labour.

492.
JOHN COX (19)
, Burglary in the dwelling-house of
William Bell, and stealing three coats, his property.

WILLIAM BELL . I am a clothier, and live at 21, Wandsworth-road—about 1 a.m. on 27th February I was called by the police, and found a shutter forced open in the doorway sufficiently wide to admit a man—I missed three coats, two of which are here—I had shut up my shop the night previous about 11.30—all was then secure—I do not know the prisoner—I saw the two coats on the prisoner directly after I was called out.

JOHN MILRUP (Policeman W.) On 27th February I saw three men standing by the shutters of 21, Wands worth Road—I don't recognise the prisoner—I had another man in custody—I blew my whistle and chased them and caught another man named No it, who has been dis
charged—ten minutes after I had him in custody the prisoner was brought back by Baker, who had heard my whistle and stopped the prisoner, who was wearing this coat over his own—I did not see the coat picked up.

SAMUEL BARKER (Policeman 551 W.) On 27th February, about 1.20 a.m., I heard a whistle, and saw the prisoner run into Archer-street from Bord-street from the direction of Wandsworth-road—he ran by me; I tried to stop him, and then ran after him—he ran into Miles-street, and in a dark place threw himself into a garden and was going to crawl into the area—I took him; he was wearing this coat—I made inquiries and found the shop had been forced open—I took him to the station, where I found another man in Milrup's custody—I went back and found this coat doubled up by the side of the kerb where I had first took up the chase.

p.hi: The Prisoner, in his statement before the Magistrate and in his defence said that he picked the coat up.

div1.p:
GUILTY .†—
Six Months' Hard Labour.

493.
JOHN MORGAN (25)
, Robbery with violence on
Elizabeth Sharpe, and stealing a bag and other articles her property.

ELIZABETH SHARPE . I am a widow, living at 9, Freeschool Street—on April 1st, about 8.30, I was walking along Tanner-street, Bermondsey—I had a bag in my hand containing post-cards and, I think, 1l. 2s. in silver—just as I went down a narrow street a man hit me with his fist between my shoulders and sent me to the other side of the road—he then seized my bag and ran away—I screamed "Stop thief!" and he threw it down—somebody picked it up and a detective caught him—the prisoner is like the man; he is about the height—he had to stoop almost as low as I was before he tore it away, and I saw him sideways.
Cross-examined by the Prisoner. You look like the man—I had a clear view of you.

ALFRED HILL . I am twelve years old, and live at 28, Mark Place—I was walking up and down Tanner Street last Wednesday week and saw a man standing up against a wall; he struck a woman and took her bag and ran across Church Street, as far as Bacon's, the tanner's, where he threw the bag down—I saw a detective stop him—the prisoner is the man.
Cross-examined. I swear you are the man, because I looked in your face—I had another boy with me at the station—he saw you running.

WILLIAM HENRY HAGUE . I shall be 15 in May—I live at 225, Wilton Road—I was in Tanner Street last Wednesday week about 8.30, and saw a man running along with a bag under his arm—a woman called out "Stop thief"—he threw it down at Bacon's tan-yard, and I saw a man pick it up—the prisoner is the man—he stopped against the arch—the detective took hold of two other men in mistake; but at last he took hold of the prisoner.
Cross-examined. I know it was you, because I ran after you and followed you right up.
JOHN BROGAN (Sergeant M). I saw the prisoner running along Charles Street followed by two youths, on the evening of last Wednesday week—I

followed him, and before I got to him I took hold of the two youths and said "What is the matter?" and in consequence of what they said I took hold of the prisoner; he looked behind and then ran faster; I caught him and said "I am a police officer, and shall take you back in the direction you have been coming from"—he said "I have done nothing"—the boys then came up and said "That is right, Sir, that is the man that knocked the lady down and stole her bag"—I said "You will have to come to the station with me"—he said "I knocked no lady down, I know nothing about it."
Cross-examined. You were not walking when I stopped you, you were running—Mrs. Sharpe gave me this bag.
ELIZABETH SHARPE (Re-examined). This is my bag and the things in it—a working man gave it to me.

p.hi: The prisoner in his defence stated that it was a case of mistaken identity.

div1.p:
GUILTY .—He then
PLEADED GUILTY to a previous conviction of felony at Southwark Police-court in November, 1885.
Four Months' Hard Labour.

494.
FREDERICK PRICE and
HENRY PRICE
, Robbery with violence on
Charles Blatcher, and stealing a watch and chain, his property.
MR. HUGGINS Prosecuted; MR. BROUN Defended.

CHARLES BLATCHER . I live at 25, Commercial Street, Commercial Road, E.—on Saturday night, about 20 minutes to 7, I was walking along Lancaster Street, and as I was crossing from Southwood Street, the taller prisoner gave me two blows in the neck and knocked me down, and as I was getting up, Frederick Price took my watch and chain from me—I drew this rule out of my pocket to strike him, and he gave them to me back, and they both made off—I went up the street and saw two friends home with whom I was with, and then saw two little boys, and in consequence of what they said, I went to 4, St. George's Court, London Market—I took a constable with me—he knocked a rat-tat at the door—one of the prisoners came up and then went back again—the constable then walked upstairs—I went with him—he knocked at the front-room door, but no one answered, and we walked in and saw the two prisoners there—the constable asked me whether I recognised anyone there, and I turned to the small one and said, "Put on your clothes"—he was in his shirt-sleeves—he didn't do so, and I called on the policeman to make him, which he did, and I then said, "I shall charge him with stealing my watch and knocking me down," and gave them in charge—I have had abscesses in my throat ever since the blow, and have had to attend St. Thomas's Hospital—there is a hoarseness in the throat now—the value of my watch was 1l.

Cross-examined. I only showed the rule to the short prisoner, the other one ran off—I had passed them previously in Lane Boad—it is an ordinary two-foot rule, and as soon as I showed him it he made off—I got to this house directly after the robbery, about 10 minutes to 7—they were behind me when this occurred—I was perfectly sober—I saw Louisa Smith as I was coming from the station—she spoke to me first—I ob
served no one else in the street at the time.
Re-examined. They also struck my brother and knocked him down.
BENJAMIN POLLING (Policeman 18 MR). On 27th February I was in Newington Causeway, and saw the prosecutor, and in consequence of

what he told me I went to 5, St. George's Market, with him and his brother, I believe—the house is occupied by a man named Skinner—I asked whether there were any young men there—I then went to No. 4—that belongs to Skinner as well—a man came on to the stairs, and then went back—I went upstairs with the prosecutor, and saw the prisoners sitting by the fire getting their tea—I said, "Do you see anybody here you know?"—he pointed to Frederick, and asked him to put his coat and hat on—he did so, and he then said, "I am positive Frederick is one, and I believe Henry is the other"—I took them to the station, where Frederick was put in the dock, and a witness named Smith said she was sure they were the men—in reply to the charge Henry said, "All right, I will go to the station and prove my brother's innocence"—when the charge was read over to them at the station they made no reply.

Cross-examined. The prosecutor said he should know him better if he had his clothes on, and after they were on he said he was sure he was the man—I have made enquiries about these men; they bear very good characters, Frederick works at a Mrs. Waghorn's and the other one works where his mother lives.
Re-examined. I believe they have lost their work through this.

WILLIAM BLATCHER . I am the brother of the prosecutor—on 27th February, I was in Lane Street, about 20 yards in front of my brother, I heard him call out and ran towards him, he was getting up off the kerb, the two prisoners were in front of him, and the shorter one struck me and knocked me down; on getting up they ran away down St. George's Market—I and my brother went there and saw two boys, and in con
sequence of what they said I went and got a policeman and then went to 4, St. George's Market, and saw the prisoners there—I am positive the prisoners are the men.

Cross-examined. It was getting dark—I believe my brother was in front of the prisoners when I saw them—I did not see the rule (produced)—I have not seen the watch since—I did not see the woman Louisa Smith there—it is about four or five minutes' walk from the place where this robbery took place to the place where we found the prisoners—I am positive these are the two men, although I had only seen them for two or three minutes.

LOUISA SMITH . I live at 9, Staple Street, Long Lane, Bermondsey—on the Saturday night, 27th February, between six and seven there was a bit of a bother at the corner of Lancaster Street, and I saw the tall prisoner strike the prosecutor, and then the short one went to take his watch—I was about four or five yards away—I could not swear that these are the two men that I saw—I am an unfortunate—I saw a man and prosecutor's brother, and a woman and a baby there besides—the prosecutor struck his brother with the rule by mistake.
NOT GUILTY .
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, MAY 3RD, 1886.
